algorithm.title: N-body Algorithm
algorithm.subtitle: Understand the physics behind SolarSim
algorithm.explanation: The N-body algorithm simulates gravitational interaction between multiple celestial bodies. It calculates the forces between each pair of objects and updates their positions and velocities.
algorithm.learnMore: Read more about how our algorithm works.
algorithm.pageDescription: Learn how the N-body problem is used to model the solar system
algorithm.howItWorks: How does the N-body algorithm work?

introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.paragraph1: The N-body algorithm is a method to simulate the motion of multiple objects that attract each other through gravity. Think of stars, planets, or other celestial bodies that exert mutual influence.
introduction.paragraph2: The algorithm calculates how strong the gravitational force is that other objects exert on each individual object. Based on these forces, the velocities and positions are adjusted. Since every object must be compared with every other one, the algorithm becomes very intensive as the number of objects increases.
introduction.paragraph3: We apply this algorithm to planets and comets in the solar system, which are the objects in the N-body algorithm.

gravity.title: Gravity
gravity.description: Each object exerts a force on another object according to Newton’s law. As a result, the force is different for every object.

timeIteration.title: Time Iteration
timeIteration.description: The algorithm is repeated in small intervals to continuously recalculate velocity and direction.

barnesHut.title: Barnes-Hut Algorithm
barnesHut.description: The Barnes-Hut algorithm is an optimization of the standard N-body algorithm and is nearly identical in most respects. We use Barnes-Hut because it is more efficient and faster. The algorithm speeds up calculations using a hierarchical data structure. This organizes objects in a tree-like structure. We use a Quadtree, which divides the solar system into rectangles, and only rectangles containing objects are loaded into memory.

visualization.title: Visualization
visualization.canvasText: As you can see, there is a maximum of one circle per rectangle. This ensures that calculations don’t need to go too deep in all areas (imagine the entire canvas full of tiny rectangles — it would be much less efficient). The Barnes-Hut algorithm can also determine whether certain objects are far enough apart and then group them together (e.g., if a planet is in the bottom-right, the algorithm can group top-left planets as they belong to the same parent rectangle).

questions.question: Is SolarSim free?
questions.answer: Yes! SolarSim is completely free. We want the web application to be accessible to everyone to gain knowledge without paying.

questions.question: What is the accuracy of SolarSim?
questions.answer: SolarSim works with an N-body algorithm that ensures planets react to each other. This algorithm is simplified but follows the fundamental principles of physics.

questions.question: Can you share your solar systems with others?
questions.answer: This is not currently possible. You can save your created designs under the My Designs tab.

header.title: About SolarSim
header.text: Discover the wonders of the universe with our interactive web application for simulating solar systems.

features.title: Discover the Powerful Features
features.text: Our web application offers a range of unique and innovative features to explore the universe:

list.item1: Solar System Simulation: Simulate realistic solar systems with accurate physics, including gravity and orbits.
list.item2: Planet Management: Add or remove planets to design your own solar system.
list.item3: Collision Simulations: Experiment with planetary collisions and observe the dynamic effects.
list.item4: Color Blindness Mode: Simulate different forms of color blindness (protanopia, deuteranopia, tritanopia) for accessibility and education.
list.item5: Intuitive Interface: A user-friendly interface suitable for both beginners and experts.

technology.title: Advanced Technology
technology.text: Our application uses advanced technologies to provide a smooth and realistic experience:

list.item1: N-Body algorithm: simulates the movement and mutual forces of multiple objects attracting each other according to gravity.
list.item2: Modern Web Technologies: Built with HTML5, CSS3, and JavaScript for broad compatibility.
list.item3: Responsive Design: Works seamlessly on desktops, tablets, and mobile devices.

aboutSection.title: About the Application
aboutSection.text1: The Solar System Simulation was developed with the goal of making the universe accessible to everyone. Whether you're a student, teacher, or space enthusiast, our application offers a unique way to explore the dynamics of solar systems.
aboutSection.text2: With a focus on accessibility, performance, and education, our application combines advanced technology with a user-friendly experience. We continue to improve the application with new features and optimizations.

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.text1: When designing this website, we paid special attention to accessibility. We understand that not everyone perceives colors in the same way. That's why SolarSim implements the ability to simulate different forms of color blindness.
